nodes.bodyText: The Optional is unfortunate. Once we split the AST from the IR, we can have an abstraction for tuple types that can have 0 fields -- we can then represent a VALUES that produces rows with no columns as a list of empty tuples.

As long as it is List<Expression>, I can see no better way than to wrap it in Optional.
At first, I tried to create Row with no fields. Even though it is legal to create, it fails to evaluate.
Yes, I know. Not asking for any changes -- just commenting on what would be desirable in the longer term.
This shouldn't be necessary. The branch below should be able to handle evaluating a Row expression, just like any other expression.
This is ok for now, but it should eventually be modeled as a whole-row cast and moved to an optimizer rule. Please add a TODO.
This shouldn't be necessary. The analyzer should be able to analyze Row expressions (and their elements), as well.

I wanted to take advantage of analyzing Row items separately in case some of them are non-deterministic and other are deterministic. When analyzing them one by one, we still can build domains for the deterministic columns.
In theory, the result may be a Row expression with partially constant-folded items. In that case, we want to go through the same treatment as above.

The same treatment as above means that we return TRUE_LITERAL from the method if we find any unresolved item. I just copied this behavior for non-Row expressions.
The predicate extractor could be further improved to only skip a single column in such case.
The rewriter should be able to handle the case of a Row expression natively, so this branch shouldn't be needed.

Yes... I found I needed to extract the case of Row expression because of SimplifyExpressions.
It uses the LiteralEncoder which turns a Row into something else. I had to process the Row by field and then put it back together so that it remained a Row at the top level.

Format as:
new ValuesNode(node.getId(), newOutputs, newRows)
Why is this needed? The expression printer should be able to print a Row expression directly.

I wanted to preserve the result for all "regular" rows.
Row expression renders as "ROW(..."
